Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Cultural and Social Dimensions of Anti-Mullerian Hormone Screening Technologies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Demographic shifts in the United States, including a later average age of first birth have significantly changed how women and couples navigate family planning. For women, age is one of the best predictors of fertility: that is, whether a woman will be able to conceive. Younger women are typically more fertile, and ability to conceive declines until a woman reaches menopause. However, the age at which an individual woman becomes less fertile varies depending on many factors unique to her individual body, including genetic makeup, diet, lifestyle, and environment. Over the past decade, medical providers have increased the use of a simple blood test to measure a woman's anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) level, a hormone secreted by a woman's remaining pool of eggs. AMH level has been used in some medical settings as an indicator of fertility, with lower values suggesting reduced fertility. AMH screening is a low-cost fertility test and is becoming more widely available in the United States. As AMH testing is becoming more widespread, it is important to understand how women are using test results as a tool in family planning and to navigate their biological parenthood options. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology in methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, the project would enhance scientific understanding by broadly disseminating its findings to organizations invested in discovering more effective means of improving public health.

Moira Kyweluk, under the supervision of Dr. Thomas McDade of Northwestern University, will explore the cultural and social dimensions of AMH testing. The research will take place at two locations where AMH testing is common: first, at a network of private clinics that offer fertility testing for low out-of-pocket costs directly to consumers and second, at a large research hospital fertility clinic where testing is often a part of family planning using reproductive technologies like egg freezing and in vitro fertilization. The project uses anthropology methods including careful observation and recording of conversations in both clinics, as well as interviews with patients and providers who deliver test results. Qualitative data will help the research team understand why and when women seek AMH testing, as well as the role of romantic partners, family and social networks on accessing fertility testing and taking action using test results. Importantly, this project will gather data on experiences with low-cost fertility testing from women from diverse socioeconomic statuses, races, ethnicities and sexual orientations, deliberately including women often overlooked in research on reproductive technologies, since most patients who have access to fertility medical care in the United States and thus comprise the majority of research participants are white and affluent. Ultimately, data from this project will be important in helping women and providers make decisions about when, whether, and how to take this sort of fertility test since it can have impacts on family planning decisions, emotional health, and social life. Early fertility screening and ongoing screening throughout a woman's life could soon become a standard of care. Information from these interviews will be available to the public to give women more information about others' experiences with elective AMH testing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project gathered ethnographic data as a component of a doctoral dissertation project in anthropology at Northwestern University. The goal of the research was to understand how ovarian reserve testing is used and understood by women in the United States. A woman’s egg supply or “ovarian reserve” declines over time until menopause. Ovarian reserve testing describes a series of blood-based laboratory hormone tests as well as imaging procedures to visualize the ovaries and assess ovarian reserve. This research found that although ovarian reserve values are primarily used for patients experiencing infertility, these tests are of interest to individuals who have not yet tried to conceive but may be interested in future biological parenthood. Although physicians and other clinicians in reproductive endocrinology and infertility (REI), obstetrics and gynecology (OB-GYN), and other areas of reproductive healthcare are careful to present the limitations of these tests to predict ability to conceive, this research demonstrated patients often give the test results greater or lesser meaning and importance depending on their individual life circumstances. Identity, cultural norms, and romantic and social entanglements impacted how, whether, and when women sought out ovarian reserve testing, and how they shaped the meaning of test results about their fertility potential and ideal family planning timeline. This reshaping of medical infomration is a key finiding, and is simliar to findings from other medical anthropology projects on medical testing and screening technologies in the United States.

Demographic shifts in the United States, including a later average age of first birth have significantly changed how women and couples navigate family planning, and ovarian reserve testing is a component of downstream assisted reproductive technologies (ART) like in vitro fertilization (IVF) and or fertility preservation (i.e. egg “freezing”). This research answered questions still left open by previous work in medical anthropolgoy, specifically how “pre-pregnant” women are navigating the earlier timeline for considering their fertility offered by ovarain reserve testing. Project data from interviews with clinicians and patients in a range of settings where ovarian reserve testing is available are valuable across multiple disciplines, including social studies of science, the anthropology of reproduction, clinical medicine, and public health.

The broader impacts of this work include sharing qualitative data widely in academic and popular press publications. Data from this project will be important in helping women and providers make decisions about when, whether, and how to use ovarian reserve testing, since it can have clear impacts on family planning decisions, emotional health, and social life. This project deliberately gathered data on the experiences of individuals across socioeconomic statuses, races, ethnicities, and sexual orientations, deliberately including those often overlooked in research on reproductive technologies, since many people in the United States do not have medical insurance coverage for these infertility services. Early, low-cost hormone screening and ongoing ovarian reserve testing has already become widespread, particuarly with egg freezing technology becoming more mainstream and less costly. Information from these interviews will be available to the public to give women more information about others’ experiences with elective ovarian testing and provide context on this important new option in reproductive healthcare.

Modified by: Moira A Kyweluk

This research found that although ovarian reserve values are primarily used for patients experiencing infertility, these tests are of interest to individuals who have not yet tried to conceive but may be interested in future biological parenthood.
